eligibleDeductions.note: These deductions are subtracted from total income to arrive at chargeable income

deductions.name: National Housing Fund (NHF) Contributions
deductions.description: Contributions made by the individual under the National Housing Fund
deductions.explanation: NHF contributions are mandatory for employees earning above ₦30,000 per month. The contribution is 2.5% of basic salary and is tax-deductible, meaning it reduces your taxable income.
qualifyingConditions: Must be actual contributions made during the year of assessment

deductions.name: National Health Insurance Scheme (NHIS) Contributions
deductions.description: Contributions made by the individual under the National Health Insurance Scheme
deductions.explanation: NHIS contributions provide health insurance coverage. These contributions are tax-deductible, reducing your taxable income. Keep records of your NHIS contributions.
qualifyingConditions: Must be actual contributions made during the year of assessment

deductions.name: Pension Contributions (Pension Reform Act)
deductions.description: Contributions made by the individual under the Pension Reform Act
deductions.explanation: Pension contributions to a Retirement Savings Account (RSA) are tax-deductible. These contributions help you save for retirement while reducing your current tax liability. Keep records of your pension contributions.
qualifyingConditions: Must be contributions under the Pension Reform Act
Must be actual contributions made during the year of assessment

deductions.name: Interest on Loans for Owner-Occupied Residential House
deductions.description: Interest paid on loans for developing an owner-occupied residential house
deductions.explanation: If you took a loan to build or buy your primary residence (the house you live in), the interest you pay on that loan is tax-deductible. This helps reduce your taxable income. Keep records of your mortgage interest payments.
qualifyingConditions: Must be interest on loan for owner-occupied residential house
Must be actual interest paid during the year of assessment
House must be your primary residence

deductions.name: Life Insurance Premiums
deductions.description: Annual amount of annuity or premium paid in respect of insurance on life or deferred annuity
deductions.explanation: Life insurance premiums and annuity payments are tax-deductible. This includes premiums for insurance on your own life, your spouse's life, or deferred annuities. These payments reduce your taxable income.
qualifyingConditions: Must be annual amount paid during the year preceding the year of assessment
Covers insurance on individual's life or spouse's life

deductions.name: Rent Relief
deductions.description: Rent relief of 20% of annual rent paid, subject to maximum of ₦500,000
deductions.explanation: Rent relief allows you to deduct 20% of the annual rent you paid, up to a maximum of ₦500,000. For example, if you paid ₦3,000,000 in rent, you can claim ₦600,000 (20%), but it's capped at ₦500,000. You must accurately declare the actual rent paid with supporting documents.
deductions.calculationMethod: 20% of annual rent paid, capped at ₦500,000
qualifyingConditions: Must accurately declare actual amount of rent paid
Must provide relevant information as prescribed by tax authority
Maximum relief is ₦500,000 even if 20% of rent exceeds this amount
deductions.formula: Rent Relief = min(20% of annual rent, ₦500,000)

housingAllowance.explanation: Housing allowance is a deduction based on your basic salary. You can claim up to 25% of your basic salary as housing allowance. If you pay rent, you can claim the actual rent paid (with receipts) up to this 25% limit.
conditions: Must be part of employment package
Or actual rent paid with receipts

transportAllowance.explanation: Transport allowance is a deduction for transportation expenses. You can claim up to ₦200,000 annually for transport-related expenses such as fuel, vehicle maintenance, or public transport costs. Keep receipts as proof.

medicalAllowance.description: Medical Allowance - Actual expenses with receipts
medicalAllowance.explanation: Medical allowance allows you to deduct actual medical expenses you paid during the tax year. This includes doctor visits, medications, hospital bills, and health insurance premiums. You must keep receipts as proof of these expenses.
medicalAllowance.note: No maximum limit, but must be actual expenses with receipts

educationAllowance.description: Education Allowance - For self and dependents
educationAllowance.explanation: Education allowance allows you to deduct actual education expenses for yourself and your dependents. This includes tuition fees, school supplies, books, and other educational costs. Keep receipts as proof.
educationAllowance.note: No maximum limit, but must be actual expenses with receipts

pensionContribution.explanation: Pension contributions to a Retirement Savings Account (RSA) are tax-deductible up to 25% of your income. This means if you contribute to a pension fund, up to 25% of your income can be deducted from your taxable income, reducing the tax you pay.

nhfContribution.explanation: NHF (National Housing Fund) contributions are mandatory for employees earning above ₦30,000 per month. The contribution is 2.5% of your basic salary and is tax-deductible, meaning it reduces your taxable income.
nhfContribution.note: Mandatory for qualifying employees, voluntary for others

businessExpenses.explanation: Business expenses are costs you incur to run your business. These are fully deductible from your business income, reducing your taxable profit. Common business expenses include rent, utilities, salaries, supplies, and marketing costs.
businessExpenses.note: Must be expenses incurred wholly, exclusively, and necessarily for business purposes

capitalAllowances.description: Capital Allowances - Depreciation on business assets (First Schedule, Part I)
capitalAllowances.section: First Schedule, Part I, Table I
capitalAllowances.explanation: Capital allowances allow you to claim depreciation (reduction in value over time) on business assets as deductions. This reduces your taxable profit. Different types of assets have different allowance rates. These are annual allowances (no initial allowance under 2025 Act).

rates.description: Buildings, agricultural assets, masts, intangible assets, heavy transportation
Motor vehicles, software, other capital assets

capitalAllowances.note: All allowances are annual rates. No initial allowance under Nigeria Tax Act 2025. Allowances are claimed annually until asset is fully written off or disposed.

exemptSupplies: Crude petroleum oil and feed gas
Goods for humanitarian donor funded projects
zeroRatedSupplies: Live cattle, goats, sheep and poultry
Electricity (GENCOs to Grid/NBET, TCN to DISCOs)

companyDonations.explanation: Companies can deduct donations made to qualifying institutions, up to 10% of profit before tax for the year.
qualifyingRecipients: Religious, charitable, educational and scientific institutions
Bodies recognised under Diplomatic Immunities and Privileges Act
Pandemic, natural disaster or other public emergency interventions

researchDevelopment.explanation: Companies can deduct research and development expenses up to 5% of turnover for the year.
